properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Westerly winds will reach 90 kilometres per hour today. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T01:23:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T09:24:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0699078111.2019
Area: Inukjuak, Sanikiluaq
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 20 centimetres of snow is expected over these regions through Sunday evening. Flurries at times heavy and blowing snow are also possible as the cold front moves through in the second half of the day, potentially giving significantly reduced visibilities. Temperatures will also drop rapidly in its wake. Conditions are expected to gradually improve overnight Sunday night; however, additional snowfall accumulations are expected during the day on Monday. Travel conditions could be poor at times. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T03:01:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T11:02:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4045078993.2019
Area: Waskaganish, Joutel - Matagami area, Miquelon - Desmaraisville area, La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Quévillon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow is falling in west-central parts of the province. The snow is expected to gradually move southwards tonight and is forecast to end from north to south beginning early Sunday morning. In the Crowsnest Pass region, snow is expected to end early Sunday afternoon with the highest snowfall amounts focused near Waterton Lakes National Park. In the Cypress Hills region, snow is forecast to end Sunday afternoon, with the more intense band of snow moving through the region overnight. General amounts of 10 to 20 cm are forecast, although amounts may reach 30 cm in localized areas near the B.C. and Alberta-USA border. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T19:59:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T04:05:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2197325298.2019

properties.Summary:

In the Crowsnest Pass region, the highest snowfall amounts are expected to fall near Waterton Lakes National Park. General amounts of 10 to 20 cm are forecast, although amounts may reach 30 cm in localized areas near the B.C. and Alberta-USA border. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. properties.Title: Flash Freeze Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures are forecast to fall rapidly this afternoon or early this evening to well below freezing due the passage of an Arctic cold front. Ponding water, slush, and any falling precipitation will freeze as the temperature drops. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Visibilities along the Kivalliq coastline are expected to worsen later today and tonight as northwest winds strengthen into the 40 to 50 km/h range, which will give blowing snow. On Monday, conditions will deteriorate further with near blizzard conditions likely. The near blizzard will persist Monday night and Tuesday, with improvement not likely until some time on Tuesday night. The situation will continue to be monitored and blizzard warnings may be issued if needed. The coastal Kivalliq communities should be prepared for a multi-day period of strong northerly winds that will very likely produce, at least, periods of near-blizzard conditions from tonight through Tuesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T01:48:06-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong westerly winds will reduce visibilities to near zero today. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow causing widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: local snowfall possibly reaching 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 60 km/h causing blowing snow. Locations: Inverness County - south of Mabou, Victoria county, Pictou and Antigonish counties, and Kings county, Prince Edward Island. Time frame: until late this afternoon or early this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T00:59:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T14:23:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1474798509.2019

Remarks: Onshore flurries and occasional snow squalls are expected to persist until this afternoon. Poor visibilities can be expected within the snow squalls. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally 15 to possibly 30 cm over the Highlands. Maximum Wind Gusts: 60 km/h causing blowing snow. Location: Inverness County - Mabou and north, including the Highlands. Time frame: until late this afternoon or early this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T00:59:28-00:00

Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow continues today. Snow has arrived as expected and will continue today. Total snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are likely, with a few pockets of 10 to 15 cm possible especially near the Quebec border. In addition to today's snowfall, there is a risk of a brief but intense snow squall as a sharp Arctic cold front moves through. Visibility may suddenly drop to near zero with this snow squall. Snow squall watches and warnings may be issued if necessary. Road conditions are likely to be poor at times. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. The snow may taper off for a few hours tonight in the wake of the cold front, However, more snow with additional accumulation is expected Monday as a disturbance from the Midwestern States crosses Northeastern Ontario. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T02:27:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T10:28:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0567698817.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills continues. The first major cold wave of the winter has moved into portions of the northern prairies and is expected to persist well into next week. Although temperatures will warm slightly during the day, wind chills during the overnight periods will return to the minus 45 to minus 50 range in northern Saskatchewan. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T02:10:56-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. A weak disturbance crossing northern Yukon will give strong east winds of 50 km/h gusting to 70 near the Richardson Mountains this morning. These strong winds will give reduced visibility in blowing snow and cold wind chills near minus 25. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-08T21:54:17-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Temperatures in the minus thirties combined with northwest winds of 15 km/h are resulting in extreme wind chills near the warning threshold of -45 over far northern Manitoba early this morning. Conditions should moderate slightly later this morning, but extreme wind chills will return tonight and persist most of Monday and into Tuesday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T02:36:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T10:37:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3902230773.2019
Area: Brochet, Tadoule Lake

properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A strong low pressure system will track north into western Hudson Strait today. As it approaches, very strong southeast winds and snow will develop over southern Baffin Island, with the worst conditions expected at Kimmirut. Blizzard conditions are likely to develop at Kimmirut late this morning and persist throughout the afternoon and evening with gradual improvement beginning overnight. Southeast winds gusting to 90 km/h combined with falling snow will give visibilities of 400 metres or less during the blizzard. Total snowfall amounts will be in the 10 to 20 cm range. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T07:41:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T15:42:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1441016722.2019
Area: Kimmirut
properties.Author: Environment Canada
